column1: Mulligan, Gyllenhaal, and Oxenbould shine in Dano's fiery 1960s drama about a fracturing family.

Carey Mulligan is giving a career best performance very reminiscent to Jessica Lange in Blue Sky and we all know how that turned out for THAT Oscar winner. The depths of emotional despair she exudes are dizzying, but spot on.
The performances are smartly delivered, with Gyllenhaal at his most hang-dogged at times and Mulligan her beautiful but unsure self.

Dano is 34, his partner and screenwriter Zoe Kazan is 35, and they have adapted a novel by Ford, who is 74. [ Mulligan] the tremulous center of it all, is 33. I cite the ages with certain wonderment at the seeming authenticity of Dano's work in every way.
This closely observed family portrait, a study of loss and trauma, comes in tones of pervasive sadness.
Wildlife is a film of haunting pain that's often left unspoken, but that crackles with inescapable force and feeling.
What Dano aims for is something trickier: understanding these characters and the forces animating their decisions without necessarily identifying with them.
For his part, Dano adheres to a delicate realization, without a false note. [Full review in Spanish]
A small-scale and affecting directorial debut.
It's a remarkable and poignant debut that's worth seeking out.
Mulligan, Gyllenhaal, and Oxenbould shine in Dano's fiery 1960s drama about a fracturing family.

Carey Mulligan is giving a career best performance very reminiscent to Jessica Lange in Blue Sky and we all know how that turned out for THAT Oscar winner. The depths of emotional despair she exudes are dizzying, but spot on.
The performances are smartly delivered, with Gyllenhaal at his most hang-dogged at times and Mulligan her beautiful but unsure self.

Dano is 34, his partner and screenwriter Zoe Kazan is 35, and they have adapted a novel by Ford, who is 74. [ Mulligan] the tremulous center of it all, is 33. I cite the ages with certain wonderment at the seeming authenticity of Dano's work in every way.
This closely observed family portrait, a study of loss and trauma, comes in tones of pervasive sadness.
Wildlife is a film of haunting pain that's often left unspoken, but that crackles with inescapable force and feeling.
What Dano aims for is something trickier: understanding these characters and the forces animating their decisions without necessarily identifying with them.
For his part, Dano adheres to a delicate realization, without a false note. [Full review in Spanish]
A small-scale and affecting directorial debut.
It's a remarkable and poignant debut that's worth seeking out.

[A] solemn and soul-searching period piece family drama. Wildlife is an affecting, low-key gem of an absorbing story that packs an unassuming punch regarding a portrait of a dysfunctional family unit lost in heartbreak and indecision... thought-provoking
Such a superb showcase for fine, fine actors.
Don't treat this as a family's end when it's actually three separate lives readying new beginnings.
The emotions are sometimes raw, but there are no hysterics, no melodrama, and the performances are measured and honest.

If the strikingly handsome, emotionally chilly Wildlife itself occasionally runs the risk of feeling a bit like we're watching a still life, that's ultimately eclipsed by Dano's exceptional work with his actors and the film's wondrous visuals.
There are many reasons to cherish tender family drama Wildlife. Chief among them is Carey Mulligan, who gives by some margin the finest performance of her career

Even with the dissolution of love at the forefront, this film finds love, humor, and several jaw-dropping moments that make this one of the strongest dramas this year. It's as if Dano is celebrating the past, while satisfied with starting a new chapter.
Dano and Kazan have deftly adapted a bittersweet, haunting work into a movie that retains the tone while bending the argument toward pragmatic feminism.
Not always easy to read, Wildlife nonetheless entangles us in the lives of characters who defy easy definition.
An excellent directing debut by Paul Dano. A subtle, yet powerful family drama, that includes a career-best performance by Carey Mulligan. [Full review in Spanish]
Adapted from Richard Ford's book of the same name, Dano and his partner Zoe Kazan have made one of the most insightful, deeply intelligent, and profoundly moving films of the year in Wildlife.
[Mulligan] has an expert deadpan too, delivering lines sharpened like arrowheads.
...an astonishingly assured directorial debut for Paul Dano, who might have played Joe a decade or two ago.
Dano can direct, the cast can act, and you will be bummed out for all the right reasons.
Expect Dano to find work behind a camera again.
The jittery physicality of Mulligan's portrayal is frequently surprising.
Wildlife starts slow, but the performances bring you in.

Ed Oxenbould starred in the kid movie Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day. So it makes sense that he's now co-starring in what should be titled - - Paul Dano and his Terrible, (etc), Very Bad First Movie. Just kidding. Sort of.
An impressive domestic drama illustrating emotional literary and the spiritual practice of impermanence.
A small, poignant story that indicates Dano and Kazan may have a big future in movies.
From the outset, Dano's direction is nicely understated. Joe realizes something is wrong between his parents, but he does not know what it is or why. He simply feels the tension in the household.
In a film of stand-out performances, Mulligan's is the most fully realized, unspooling Jeanette's desperation and discovering suppressed, buried pieces of herself from moment to moment.
Carey Mulligan is mesmerizing in poetic portrait of unraveling family.
Carey Mulligan delivers another outstanding performance in Paul Dano's directorial debut. "Wildlife" is a must-see!
Paul Dano's directorial debut paints an emotionally distant picture
Paul Dano's directorial debut Wildlife lands not with a thud but a slow caress, to be inhaled and ruminated on, its stagnant images billowing into your lungs.
Wildlife features some truly wonderful actors plying their craft at the highest of levels. And I didn't believe a one of them for a cold minute.
A quiet film, but it sneaks up on you, gaining in emotional urgency as it goes on.
[Dano] and his co-writer/real-life partner Zoe Kazan have drawn from their rich theatrical trainint to craft an internal drama that resembles classical directors with stage origins.
Although it is actually quite a talky film, it's not unnecessarily expository.

Mulligan finally emerges from the shadow of An Education, giving us a seemingly grown woman, in all her charm and selfishness, who still has some growing to do - an education, just of a different sort.
Wildlife...feels like one of those films you expect to be brilliant only to realise halfway through that it's merely OK.
Jeanette is a wonderfully puzzling creation: at times you applaud her spirit and liveliness, at others you wish she'd remember to protect her poor son from her wild excesses.
Dano is not yet an Antonioni, but he has an eye for alienation which should serve him well in the future.
... a portrait of the artist as a young man, [the artist] just doesn't know it yet.
Mulligan is imperious in an excellent three-way cast, as woodwinds and setting sunlight float through the frame.
With the exception of Mulligan, whose sharp-edged performance begins to overpower the otherwise muted, rather mannered film, it feels too neatly mapped as a whole.
Dano and his cohorts have made an evocative film that will quietly break hearts but should also make Oklahomans' swell with state pride.
"Wildlife" is one of the best movies of the year, and a hard one to shake.
The harder Dano tries to make the movie feel cinematic (and boy, does he!), the more stagy it feels.
[Dano's] restraint and acute grasp of nuance are mirrored by three outstanding central performances.

Mulligan is brilliant at showing her internal conflict, the swings between doubt and determination, and the need to be loved as a woman, as she tries to find a better place for herself and her son in an unequal world.
An assured debut from Dano and a genuinely heartbreaking portrayal of regret from Carey Mulligan with a final scene that will break your heart.
This is a movie that delights in confusion and in not giving its viewers enough of a reason to stay interested in that murkiness of its very unlikable characters.
"Wildlife," is a perfectly measured drama boasting some powerhouse acting.
Dano pulls magnificent performances from his cast. That, along with beautiful cinematography and a patient-but-not-slow pace, makes "Wildlife" a magnificent debut.

Dano is so attuned to his characters and their despair and vulnerabilities that even when they behave hatefully, as they do, or become revoltingly self-absorbed, as they do, you can't just wash your hands of them. You care.
An intimate, low-key family affair that slowly gives way to a narrative where aggravation, pain and resentment simmer beneath the landscape ready to flare up.
The standout performance may be that of young Ed Oxenbould. What are they putting in teenagers' cereal these days?

Wildlife marks an accomplished directorial debut for actor Paul Dano who - along with writing partner Zoe Kazan - transforms Ford's 1960s-set tale of a fracturing family into a fantastic showcase for Carey Mulligan.
At times thematically heavy-handed, but nevertheless atmospheric, the film's scaffolding is its three expansive central performances, and sensitive Stephen Shore-inspired cinematography.

Most certainly an actor's movie, Wildlife's power nevertheless hinges on Dano and co-writer Zoe Kazan's script based on Richard Ford's novel, a pristine example of economic storytelling that enables each performance to intensify naturally over time.
Develops some of that restlessness reminiscent of the tormented Blanche DuBois in Tennessee Williams' classic play, A Streetcar Named Desire.
Wildlife is a quiet coming-of-age tale of lost men and women trying to redefine themselves. It may not set the world on fire but a career-best performance from Mulligan makes it worth a look.
Carrie Mulligan cinches a Best Actress Oscar nod with her dazzlingly calibrated performance as Jeanette Brinson.
A truly outstanding directorial debut from Paul Dano.
In a directorial debut of immense promise, [director Paul Dano] never makes the obvious decision, instead trying to get under the skin of his characters.
It is wide enough to take in good performances, a tersely superlative screenplay and a small-town look that you could take to the bank.
Flawlessly conceived ... Dano never abandons his young protagonist to the fireworks of his parents' behaviour; Joe might say very little, but he is always there.

The whole thing feels deflated and streeeeetched, with the story just kind of laying there... and even watching Mulligan and Gyllenhaal carefully, skillfully reveal different facets of their characters isn't enough to make Wildlife feel alive.
It is fair to say that audiences will know early on where this story is headed, but Dano's expert execution makes the journey a diverting (and at times disturbing) experience.
...chronicles the dissolution of a marriage from a particular, stunned vantage point.
A slow burn, but when it catches light, it's a wildfire.

Directed by actor Paul Dano from the 1990 novel by Richard Ford, Wildlife is a quietly intimidating experience, with three precision-tooled lead performances sharpening the edges of its tale throughout.
A beautifully observed study of an American family coming apart at the seams, it not only establishes Dano as a director to watch, but features an extraordinary performance by Mulligan.
...amounts to many ephemeral gestures, anchored by less a character and more a blank slate of a performance
Actor Paul Dano (There Will Be Blood) proves himself an adept, understated and nuanced dramatic director with his feature debut about a troubled marriage...A terrific, compelling drama.
An exquisitely rendered chamber drama...that's probing, perceptive and intriguingly allusive.
"Wildlife" is not just tame, it's for the most part lifeless, a meandering exercise with all the excitement and emotion of a two-hour stare down.
Paul Dano has created a compelling examination of the nuclear family in the 1960s and the consequences when it falls apart.
There's a rising star Wildlife.
Carey Mulligan has been confidently constructing a tasteful resume since her auspicious breakout ...but never has her light shined brighter.
Paul Dano's intelligent, well-cast adaptation of Richard Ford's novel is a cut above most such literary coming-of-age stories, with Carey Mulligan outdoing herself as the mother.

Sadly, there's nothing really ing√©nue being said with these exacting illustrations of long-gone American life, as his bow isn't much more than an interesting vanity piece, soon to be forgotten come next the next festival season of our discontent.
While it has a formal visual style, as though emphasizing how trapped its characters are, it really comes alive in the energy between the performers onscreen.
Dano has made a fine first film, a quiet and restrained study and dissection of domesticity.
Mulligan is graceful and subtle, vulnerable and scornful, domineering when covering up her many insecurities. It's a towering, commanding performance.
Mulligan gives the performance of a lifetime as two halves of the same woman - in a lot of ways, the movie is really about her.
Paul Dano has crafted a poignant directorial debut exploring a certain cultural dissatisfaction by homing in on how it affects one family.
Its color palette, compositions, retro production design and even David Lang's ("Youth") horn-based score suggest Todd Haynes directing a film inspired by an Edward Hopper painting.
The writing is attentive and the helming respectful, with Dano getting the feature to unique perspectives and dramatic sensitivity, delivering a special debut.

Brings the life-altering pain of a family falling apart to the screen with genuine realism, building to an ending image that will linger. Wildlife is more than just an outstanding debut film from Paul Dano, it's one of the best films of the year.
There is a dreamlike quality to actor Paul Dano's debut film as a director, one where everyday things and places are imbued with otherworldly beauty and time seems to stand still.
It's a bold and borderline eccentric performance by Mulligan.
I felt like I was watching a film about a play about a family and never got closer than arm's length.
It's a small film, yet it covers an immense amount of ground.
A small-scale gem with a haunting final image, Paul Dano's debut feature "Wildlife" is the story of a 1960s family quietly imploding.
First-time director Dano, who co-scripted with partner Zoe Kazan, has a knack for capturing quotidian daily struggles as well as moments of discovery that hearten or, more often, horrify.
Wildlife is a special film due to the level of talent involved, as we discover there are great depths and complexities to be mined within the apprehensions of mother, father and son.

Wildlife is an exploration of the destruction of the nuclear family through the eyes of a teenager whose wholesome views and ideas of his parents' marriage deteriorates as things begin to slowly fall apart.
A confident, melancholy drama that uses sharp observation to make larger points about the endless fissures in American family life.
The directorial debut of actor Paul Dano, this dispiriting domestic drama is somewhat salvaged by its dedication to fine acting and by moments of stillness in which such acting can flourish.
...shows Dano's confident hand behind the camera, and features Carey Mulligan in yet another career best performance.
"Wildlife" isn't dazzling entertainment but an intelligent, low-key and satisfying film with a rare respect for every character.
A slightly wobbly - if just this side of wonderful - film.
We finally decide that Dano and his actorly directorial impulses show quite a bit of promise, but that we can't wait to leave this particular family to its fate.
Come see "Wildlife" for Jake Gyllenhaal and Carey Mulligan, but stay for the young actor who plays their 14-year-old son.
Dano's film is shrewd and exacting, composed with rigor yet alert to the rhythms of its performers.
Much like his tempered onscreen persona, Paul Dano's directorial debut is quiet, considered, and deeply sensitive.
In this evocative, melancholy adaptation of a Richard Ford novel, some terrific performances balance out an uneven script that's sometimes difficult to penetrate.
Ms. Mulligan shows her character no mercy, at least on the surface; her performance is startling, and for the most part unsparing.
It's a tale we've seen plenty of times before, told deliberately and tastefully, giving no glimmers of idiosyncrasy or, frankly, personality.
Gyllenhaal and Mulligan are in fine form here, but too much of the screenplay, written by Dano and Zoe Kazan, doesn't ring true.
She's a woman out of time, and Ford's story, written 30 years ago, set 60 years ago, is strikingly resonant.
It speaks to Dano's own experience as an actor that he so generously endows his performers with the time and space to chart their characters' emotionally intense arcs.
Wildlife is both stately and messy, in the way mid-century America so often seems to look through the rearview mirror.

If the drama feels somewhat studied - though it would be more accurate to say that it simply feels thought through - it is never airless or constricted. The story maintains a steady emotional pulse alongside its meticulous accrual of details...
The whole of the film is a potent collaboration in every respect, and a remarkable directorial debut.

Working from a screenplay he wrote with partner Zoe Kazan, Dano shows not just a keen way with actors but also an alert eye for deceptively charged visuals that combine surface beauty and nagging emptiness.
The film belongs to Oxenbould, who comes of age with a role that's layered and powerfully compelling.

Carrie Mulligan ignites a blaze in actor-turned-director Paul Dano's moving familial melodrama about a 1960's housewife and mother who can't catch up with the feminist stirrings she feels inside. One word for Mulligan: Wow.
Actor Paul Dano's directorial debut... is a complex, deep dive into the psyche of a broken family in an era where the veneer of happiness is prized above all.
It's one worth making the trip to the theater for. Wildlife isn't just a great first film, it's a great film.
A confident and compassionate first film.
Impeccably acted, brilliantly written, confidently directed, and full of quiet desperation, it's rather magnificent.
Hardly a single moment over the runtime demonstrates a forceful, vigorous, or urgent vision.
With first-time director Paul Dano at the helm, Wildlife benefits from a stand-out performance from actress Carey Mulligan.
Dano doesn't appear in his own movie, but its texture is of a piece with his courteous and careful performances, where he always seems to plead fruitlessly with an unjust world.
Carey Mulligan turns in her strongest performance to date in this meticulously constructed, quietly devastating family drama.
Feminism and coming-of-age meet in Montana in Paul Dano's artfully composed adaptation of Richard Ford's novel of marriage on the rocks in 1960.

Based on the novel by Richard Ford, the film is an ambitious project for Dano and co-screenwriter Zoe Kazan, as they attempt to craft a quiet and intense chamber drama about a family eking out an existence in 1960s Montana.
It's beautifully designed and well-acted, and Mulligan's tense work as a mother who sometimes seems to be the stronger parent and sometimes the more dangerous one is exquisite.
Paul Dano's directorial debut is a scorching coming-of-age drama of a family coming apart in a Montana town threatened by wild fires.
Wildlife is a drama alive with pain and love.
Paul Dano's directorial debut is a piercing account of a family falling apart. [Full review in Spanish]
Its slow pace may not be for everyone, but Carey Mulligan and Jake Gyllenhaal are perfection in this quietly tragic directorial debut from Paul Dano.
For a debut, Dano does an excellent job providing great filmmaking and a powerful cast who are all downright amazing, and the screenplay he and Kazan adapted is even more so.
Dano magnifies the source material by pulling out extraordinary performances from his cast, most particularly Academy Award nominee Carey Mulligan and newcomer Ed Oxenbould.
Dano directs the hugely talented cast into giving three-dimensional performances that lead to a final act that isn't as spellbinding as the first two.
From this his first attempt at directing, viewers would be gratified to find Dano to be an actor's director; especially with the excellent cast he has under his helm, this is doubly rewarding.
It's the kind of piercing portrait of a family that makes you want to marinate in all of its surprising details just as you desperately want to escape its breathlessly realized pain.
It's a film of generous, meditative observation that also happens to be beautifully observed.
It's a fine dramatic production, with many outstanding performances.

Wildlife is an assured directorial debut driven by three stellar performances - an intimate period piece with weighty themes about economic insecurity and parental discontentment that continue to resonate to the modern day.
An accomplished, moving piece of filmmaking, one that cares about its characters and trusts its performers.
Dano's lack of a truly individual style is what keeps the film at a bit of a remove, but for a first outing, he can walk away gratified that things turned out as well as they did.
A competent debut, but perhaps too neat at times, Wildlife captures the feeling of the world falling away that comes with the separation of a family.
Dano's directorial debut is deceptively low-key yet compelling. And just like his most memorable screen performances, there's lots of rage roiling beneath the surface.
The look of this movie, from the costuming and production design to the cinematography, is beautiful and pitch-perfect in its evocation of small town America.
Wildlife is at once loquacious and laconic, a film in which simple words hold unspoken and unequivocal power, and the space between banal utterances become chasms.
This is a deeply humane story without heroes or villains that resonates with its honesty and top-notch performances.
Dano's direction is reminiscent of the coming-of-age lyricism of Terence Davies' best work, blended with the melancholic poetry of David Gordon Green's early films.
Dano certainly proves that he can command a tough yet tender film both technically and creatively. I, for one, can't wait to see what he does next.
Every time the film loses momentum completely, Mulligan pulls viewers back in with a quivering lip or her disarmingly sad eyes.
A haunting and elegantly handled portrait of blue-collar American family life in an era where gender inequality had major sway on income and decision-making.
Dano presents a secure directorial command. [Full Review in Spanish]
Neat and tidy as the film might be - perhaps the "wild" in that title is leading us unhelpfully astray - it gets full marks for sustaining an aura.
A delicate labour of love, the film is softly focused on the details that make up the relationships with the people closest to us; the ones that keep us together, those that break us apart.
This is an astonishingly confident debut, and a heartbreaking tale of two parents at war.
Dano steps behind the camera for the first time and barely puts a foot wrong with an early '60s-set story of family break-up seen through the eyes of a teenage boy.
What marks Dano out as one to watch, is an ending that's quiet, apt, unshowy and yet also exquisitely sad.
A quietly devastating coming of age movie dipped in poison.
The main merit of the film lies in its ability to establish a point of view. [Full review in Spanish]
The first film by actor Paul Dano as director has turned out to be the first pleasant surprise at Cannes 2018. [Full review in Spanish]
Powerhouse turns by Gyllenhaal and Mulligan, lovely visuals, terrific production design and a story that may feel familiar but quickly sets itself apart.

A sobering examination of a family falling apart under external pressure. Dano's eye for cinematic exploration does overwhelm some narrative inconsistencies but it's a solid debut, and well worth seeking out.
Dano has given us a satisfying drama of damaged lives.
A confident starting point for Dano's directorial career, it will leave you looking forward for more of his sure to be eclectic career behind the camera.
This is a superb film.
We've seen stories like Wildlife done many times before but rarely are they done with such grace and humanity.
Dano aces the formal requirements that make a good film. But there's so much that is great in this debut, and not enough that feels original.
Impeccably made, although the clinical approach is cold and off-putting.
Did Dano pick up this uncommon fledgling restraint from one of the many first-rate filmmakers for whom he's acted?

The result is a careful, deliberate, slightly distanced treatment of stormy emotions - but it's appropriate, because the characters are often as not driven not to action but to inaction by their circumstances.
With every new moment of restrained poeticism, it's astounding this is a director's first time behind the camera.

"Wildlife" could have easily dissolved into melodrama, but the fact that it doesn't is a testament to Dano's assured direction, which makes a book that, by all accounts, was deemed unfilmable, filmable.
Wildlife digs into the complexity of these dynamics, buoyed by a powerhouse performance from Carey Mulligan. And along the way it announces Paul Dano as a bona fide filmmaker.
It's striking to see such a proven actress [like Carey Mulligan] deliver what's so clearly the best work of her career, but it's unsurprising that [Paul] Dano knows what to do with his cast.
And although Jeanette acts out a few times in Wildlife, there's such precision in [Carey] Mulligan's portrayal that it eschews flashiness.
Dano, it's immediately clear, is a natural-born filmmaker, with an eye for elegant spare compositions that refrain from being too showy; they rarely get in the way of the story he's telling.
Actor Paul Dano has made a small gem in Wildlife, his first film as a director.
There are no shortage of laughs in Wildlife, but this is a fundamentally melancholy picture. It's also an assured first film from an actor who will hopefully continue to direct.
